author: By Bill Pennington
title: Ahead of the Masters, Tiger Woods Hits the Driving Range and the Back Nine
description: Woods, who is trying to return to golf after sustaining significant leg injuries in a single-car crash in February 2021, said that playing on Thursday would be a “game-time decision.”
content: AUGUSTA, Ga. — At the end of a mostly empty practice range with the Masters tournament a few days away, Tiger Woods was back in his element on Sunday. On a sunny day with temperatures near 80 degrees, a smiling Woods took about 30 fluid swings, posing in his follow-through to watch high, arcing shots against a cloudless blue sky.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyssa Lukpat
title: $4.8 Million Settlement Reached in Trooper’s Fatal Shooting of a Black Driver
description: Julian Edward Roosevelt Lewis, 60, was killed in August 2020 after a Georgia state trooper stopped him for a broken taillight.
content: The state of Georgia will pay a $4.8 million settlement to the family of a 60-year-old Black man who was fatally shot by a state trooper in 2020 during a traffic stop over a broken taillight, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alanis Thames
title: After Injury, Armando Bacot Isn’t Deterred by Quick Turnaround
description: Bacot, a North Carolina forward who returned to the semifinal against Duke after hurting his right ankle, is determined to play in Monday’s championship game against Kansas.
content: NEW ORLEANS — First, Armando Bacot laid his forehead on the court and forced himself onto his back. The pain in his right ankle was so bad that he writhed on the Superdome floor, clenching his blue Carolina jersey in his teeth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alanis Thames
title: North Carolina Wins the Battle of Tobacco Road, Retiring Krzyzewski
description: The Tar Heels will face Kansas on Monday night in the N.C.A.A. men’s championship game.
content: NEW ORLEANS — Hubert Davis put a photo of the Caesars Superdome, the site of this year’s men’s Final Four, in the North Carolina locker room on the first day of practice this season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Molly Young
title: ‘Young Mungo’ Explores Love and Violence in Emotional Technicolor
description: Douglas Stuart’s follow-up to his Booker Prize-winning novel “Shuggie Bain” is, like that novel, the story of a boy and his alcoholic mother in working-class Glasgow.
content: A critic could generate a whole book review simply by reproducing her marginalia. It would be boring to read but accurate, like an EKG printout. If the book in question were “Young Mungo,” by Douglas Stuart, it might begin with observations like “Gorgeous writing!” and “Wow,” before graduating to expletives and exclamation marks and wobbly underlines and question marks. Family-friendly adjectives do not always describe the yanking of certain heart strings in this lovely but occasionally overworked novel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: ‘Macbeth’ performances on Broadway pause after Daniel Craig tests positive for the coronavirus.
description: The show, which just began previews on Tuesday, hopes to resume on April 8.
content: Daniel Craig, who is starring in the title role of a new Broadway production of “Macbeth,” tested positive for the coronavirus on Saturday, forcing the show to cancel most of next week’s performances.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins and Benjamin Novak
title: Pro-Putin Leaders in Hungary and Serbia Set to Win Re-election
description: Viktor Orban declared victory, and Serbia’s Aleksandar Vucic seemed likely to emerge on top. Both pledged to stay out of Russia’s war in Ukraine.
content: BUDAPEST — Overshadowed by the war in Ukraine, elections on Sunday in Hungary and Serbia appear to have extended the tenures of Europe’s two most Kremlin-friendly leaders, both populist strongmen fortified by their overwhelming control of the media and cheap energy from Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for Around $1.5 Million
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cora Engelbrecht
title: Russia has committed ‘apparent war crimes,’ Human Rights Watch says.
description: The organization’s report is based on a series of interviews with eye witnesses, victims and local residents of Russia-occupied territories between Feb. 27 and March 14.
content: WARSAW — A leading human rights group said it had documented “apparent war crimes” by Russian forces against Ukrainian civilians in the occupied areas of the Chernihiv, Kharkiv and Kyiv regions in Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Goldbaum and Salman Masood
title: The Supreme Court says it will weigh in Monday on Pakistan political turmoil.
description: Opposition leaders have asked the court to allow a no-confidence vote to go forward, which would reignite efforts to oust the prime minister.
content: Hours after Prime Minister Imran Khan declared the National Assembly dissolved on Sunday, preventing a no-confidence vote that seemed sure to oust him, opposition leaders challenged the move before Pakistan’s Supreme Court.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ericka Andersen
title: Women, Do We Need an Intervention?
description: Our alcohol use has shot up, and our physical and mental health is suffering.
content: There have been a lot of jokes and memes about pandemic drinking by women, but the fact is that in the past two decades, women have often turned to alcohol more than they did in the past.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmett Lindner
title: Surrounded by War, Compassion Endures
description: Small moments of humanity still sing out in Ukraine. Times journalists shared the moments of courage and kindness they’ve witnessed while covering the conflict.
content: More than 10 million Ukrainians have been displaced and more than 4 million have fled the country since Russia invaded Ukraine on Feb. 24. Cities and towns throughout the country continue to be bombarded by Russian artillery. Some are now nearly unrecognizable. Civilians have died, families have been ripped apart and lives have been forever changed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas L. Friedman
title: Ukraine Is the First Real World War
description: In World War Wired, virtually everyone everywhere can observe the fighting at a granular level, participate in some way or be affected economically.
content: Almost six weeks into the war between Russia and Ukraine, I’m beginning to wonder if this conflict isn’t our first true world war — much more than World War I or World War II ever were. In this war, which I think of as “World War Wired,” virtually everyone on the planet can either observe the fighting at a granular level, participate in some way or be affected economically — no matter where they live.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nadav Gavrielov, Matina Stevis-Gridneff, Constant Méheut, Aurelien Breeden, Emily Cochrane and Cassandra Vinograd
title: U.S. and European leaders express outrage at the images from Bucha.
description: Russia’s Ministry of Defense called the images “staged,” saying in a statement that “not a single” civilian had been injured in the town.
content: Western officials expressed outrage on Sunday at videos and images emerging from Bucha, a town near Kyiv, that appeared to show civilian bodies scattered on the streets after Russia withdrew its troops from the area in recent days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annabelle Williams
title: Michelle Materre, Champion of Black Independent Film, Dies at 67
description: Through her distribution company and an educational series, Ms. Materre was for decades a tireless advocate for underrepresented filmmakers.
content: Michelle Materre, a distributor and educator who promoted Black women’s voices in film and released influential independent movies by Black creators, died on March 11 in White Plains, N.Y. She was 67.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Goldbaum and Salman Masood
title: Pakistan’s Prime Minister Dissolves Parliament, Blocking an Effort to Remove Him
description: Imran Khan’s actions have set up a constitutional battle over the country’s leadership. The Supreme Court is expected to address the turmoil on Monday.
content: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Prime Minister Imran Khan dissolved Pakistan’s National Assembly and called for new elections on Sunday, blocking a no-confidence vote that had been widely expected to remove him from office and plunging the country into a constitutional crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Picture? | April 4, 2022
description: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
content: 1. After looking closely at the image above (or at the full-size image), think about these three questions:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Goldbaum
title: Who is Imran Khan?
description: He was once a national hero who led Pakistan’s cricket team to a World Cup victory. Now, the embattled prime minister is fighting to stay in power.
content: Imran Khan was elected as Pakistan’s prime minister in 2018 when he ran as a nationalist promising to fight corruption, revive the country’s struggling economy and maintain an independent foreign policy that distanced Pakistan from the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Goldbaum
title: Why is the prime minister in trouble?
description: The critical blow for the leadership of Prime Minister Imran Khan of Pakistan came last year, when he appeared to lose the backing of the country’s powerful military.
content: The critical blow for the leadership of Prime Minister Imran Khan of Pakistan came last year, when he appeared to lose the backing of the country’s powerful military.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Arraf
title: Images of civilian victims in Ukraine spur some foreign volunteers to fight.
description: Ukraine has created a foreign legion, inviting foreigners with military experience to come and join the fight against Russia.
content: LVIV, Ukraine — Luis, a Mexican Army veteran, saw a photo of a wounded pregnant woman being carried out of a Ukrainian maternity hospital after a Russian airstrike and was reminded of his sister.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: On Daylight Saving, There Are More Options Than You Might Think
description: There are only so many hours of light in the day. When should we enjoy them?
content: The United States could soon be living with daylight saving time year-round if the Senate has its way.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tish Harrison Warren
title: 7 Life-Affirming Habits That Readers Picked Up During the Pandemic
description: “I am glad that something good came out of that time.”
content: Last week, I asked readers to share practices, habits, or perspectives that they have picked up during the pandemic that they’d like to carry with them in the years ahead. The response was incredible; story after story of beauty and goodness discovered in these difficult years. I teared up reading them. I texted my husband: “People are amazing.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cora Engelbrecht
title: The documentarian Mantas Kvedaravicius is reported killed in Mariupol.
description: Mr. Kvedaravicius, 45, had spent years covering the conflict in Ukraine. His work included “Mariupolis,” a searing portrait of the southern port city where he died.
content: A Lithuanian documentary filmmaker has been killed in the besieged southern city of Mariupol, according to his colleagues and the Ukrainian Defense Ministry’s information agency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By German Lopez
title: Climate Optimism
description: We have reason for hope on climate change.
content: Among the headline-grabbing wildfires, droughts and floods, it is easy to feel disheartened about climate change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gregory Cowles
title: A Canoeist Vanished. In ‘Riverman,’ Ben McGrath Sets Out to Find Him.
description: The true story of Dick Conant, a troubled and charismatic man who disappeared while paddling from New York to Florida.
content: “Riverman” opens with a mystery: a red canoe, found overturned and washed ashore in November 2014 on the swampy northern banks of Albemarle Sound in North Carolina, about 25 miles inland from Kitty Hawk. The boat is outfitted for a long haul, stuffed with bags containing electronics and reading matter and camping gear and annotated area maps, its lone paddle tethered securely to a gunwale. But ominously, there is no sign of any canoeist. Who was navigating this thing, and where to? And what has become of the missing boater?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum
title: Trevor Noah returns as host, after a dust-up with Kanye West.
description: The comedian devoted a segment of “The Daily Show” to West’s troubling online behavior, but said he didn’t ask for the rapper to lose his spot performing on the Grammys.
content: Trevor Noah, the comedian and face of “The Daily Show,” is returning to host the Grammy Awards for the second year in a row. For the 2021 show, Noah was front and center at an unconventional Grammys, with some performances pretaped and the bulk of the ceremony held outside the Staples Center (now known as the Crypto.com Arena) in Los Angeles. “On the whole, Noah made something that could have felt like several competing shows feel like one,” The New York Times pop music critic Jon Caramanica wrote.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: ‘S.N.L.’ Spends a Night at the Oscars With Will Smith
description: The comedian Jerrod Carmichael hosted this weekend’s “Saturday Night Live,” which found several ways to address the Academy Awards incident in which Will Smith slapped Chris Rock.
content: In his opening monologue on “Saturday Night Live,” the host and comedian Jerrod Carmichael swore he wouldn’t do it. “I’m not gonna talk about it,” he said. He didn’t even have to say what it was.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talya Minsberg
title: Q. & A.: How to Fuel Your Runs
description: What’s the real benefit in refueling soon after a run? Can eating mid-run help speed recovery? Your nutrition questions, answered.
content: In high school, a teammate of mine would win every 400-meter race she entered with Dorito dust still on her fingertips. A college teammate traveled to races with a jar of peanut butter and a spoon. At the New York City Marathon a few years back, I watched a group of friends shotgun beers at the starting line.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: The Next Battleground for College Basketball: How to Divide the Money
description: The N.C.A.A. has made improvements to its women’s basketball tournament. Now coaches want to see the industry overhaul a system that pays conferences nothing when women’s teams win games.
content: Update: South Carolina beat UConn to win its second national championship.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Jacobs
title: Covid and Diabetes, Colliding in a Public Health Train Wreck
description: After older people and nursing home residents, no group perhaps has been harder hit by the pandemic than people with diabetes. Experts hope policymakers will take notice, and finally get serious about tackling the nation’s diabetes crisis.
content: After an insect bite on his back became infected, David Donner, a retired truck driver in rural Alabama, waited six hours in a packed emergency room with his wife, before coronavirus vaccines were widely available. A few days later, they both began experiencing the telltale symptoms of Covid-19.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Weiner and Andrea Ellen Reed
title: Minnesota, a Mecca of Women’s Basketball, Is Having Its Moment
description: Minneapolis, the site of the women’s Final Four, has long produced outstanding players and rallied around its W.N.B.A. team, the Lynx.
content: Update: South Carolina beat UConn to win its second national championship.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Imbler
title: In the Ocean, It’s Snowing Microplastics
description: Tiny bits of plastic have infiltrated the deep sea’s main food source and could alter the ocean’s role in one of Earth’s ancient cooling processes, scientists say.
content: As long as there has been marine life, there has been marine snow — a ceaseless drizzle of death and waste sinking from the surface into the depths of the sea.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Putin Reminds West He Has Economic Weapons as Well
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, April 3, 2022.
content: “The lesson for the West is that the effectiveness of financial sanctions can only go so far absent trade sanctions.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlotta Gall and Andrew E. Kramer
title: In a Kyiv Suburb,‘They Shot Everyone They Saw’
description: With Russian forces retreating, Ukrainians in Bucha are finding scores of bodies in yards and on the roads amid mounting evidence of intentional and indiscriminate killings of civilians.
content: BUCHA, Ukraine — When a column of Russian tanks drove into the Kyiv suburb of Bucha in the first days of the war, Tetiana Pomazanko thought they held Ukrainian soldiers and went out to her front gate to see.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich
title: Why Hundreds of New York City Prosecutors Are Leaving Their Jobs
description: New burdens, low pay and pandemic malaise prompted the resignations of a fifth of the legal work force in Manhattan, the Bronx and Brooklyn.
content: New York City’s prosecutors are leaving in droves, citing pandemic burnout, low salaries and two intersecting laws that fundamentally changed the nature of their jobs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: NASA Stops Launch Rehearsal for Its Giant Moon Rocket
description: First a lightning storm, then problems with launch tower fans led to snags with a countdown and propellant loading intended as practice for the rocket’s launch.
content: NASA on Sunday morning cut short a practice countdown for its new megarocket, the Space Launch System. It is a key component of upcoming missions to return astronauts to the moon, and the agency said there was a problem with the mobile launch tower.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: For a Few Days at Augusta National, the Spotlight Shines on the Women
description: When the club held its first national women’s amateur tournament in 2019, it hoped to benefit women’s golf, especially the junior circuit. It seems to be working.
content: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Anna Davis had just turned 12 when Augusta National Golf Club, in a surprise, announced it would create a new national women’s amateur championship. On Saturday, now 16 years old, Davis won the tournament.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Siobhan Burke
title: Review: The Balletic Rise and Fall of Eva Perón
description: Celebrating its 50th anniversary, Ballet Hispánico takes on a new challenge: its first full-length ballet, with choreography by Annabelle Lopez Ochoa.
content: Ballet Hispánico, founded in 1970, has been honoring its 50th anniversary for a solid two years. On Friday at the inaugural City Center Dance Festival, the company presented the final program in this extended celebration, which got off to a rocky start with canceled performances in April 2020. Anniversary events often feel like empty fanfare, but this turned out to be a milestone, a breakthrough: the company’s first evening-length production, and a striking one at that.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘Toward the End of the Walk, a Bird Somewhere Ahead Burst Into Song’
description: Spotted at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, a sweet subway surprise and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Two Members of the Mighty Diamonds, Acclaimed Reggae Trio, Are Dead
description: Tabby Diamond, 66, was shot and killed Tuesday in Kingston, Jamaica. Bunny Diamond, 70, died three days later after a long illness.
content: Two members of the Mighty Diamonds, a Jamaican trio that helped lead the wave of roots reggae arising from the streets of Kingston to international acclaim in the 1970s, have died within days of each other.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamie Lincoln Kitman
title: After bottoming out early in the pandemic, U.S. car dealers’ profits are soaring.
description: The last time the National Automobile Dealers Association was able to hold its annual convention in person, the mood was far different. In a word, grimmer.
content: The last time the National Automobile Dealers Association was able to hold its annual convention in person, the mood was far different. In a word, grimmer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Monday Briefing: Reports of Russian Atrocities
description: Graphic images of civilian deaths may shift international diplomacy.
content: As Russian forces retreat from Kyiv, they are leaving horror in their wake: Videos and images show the bodies of civilians lying in the streets. Ukrainian officials accused Russian forces of executing civilians.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Egan
title: Anti-Asian Hate, in the 19th-Century American West
description: A debut novel traces a young Chinese woman’s coming-of-age: abandoned, trafficked — and posing as a man.
content: FOUR TREASURES OF THE SKYBy Jenny Tinghui Zhang
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Griffith
title: California Law Requiring Board Diversity Is Struck Down
description: In a blow to the state’s efforts to deal with disparities in the workplace, a judge found the law unconstitutional. It’s unclear whether the state will appeal the ruling.
content: A California law requiring diversity on corporate boards of directors has been struck down in a blow to the state’s efforts to address racial and gender disparities in the workplace.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shivani Gonzalez
title: Grammys 2022 Winners: The Complete List
description: The list of winners for the 64th annual Grammy Awards.
content: The 64th annual Grammy Awards took place Sunday night after being delayed by the Omicron variant. The show was held in Las Vegas for the first time at the MGM Grand Garden Arena, and Trevor Noah returned as the host. A majority of the awards were presented at the premiere ceremony, held before the telecast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marie Solis
title: This Week in Business: A Jobs Recovery
description: The U.S., followed by 31 other countries, announced the release of oil from their reserves to battle high gas prices. And workers at an Amazon warehouse vote to unionize.
content: The March report continued the strong gains of recent months, with U.S. employers adding 431,000 jobs. The unemployment rate declined, and now, at 3.6 percent, it is just a touch higher than it was before the pandemic. The economy has recovered more than 90 percent of the 22 million jobs lost in the spring of 2020, far surpassing initial forecasts. March’s showing may help tell a story about the changing attitudes toward the coronavirus, particularly as companies move ahead with return-to-office plans — the share of office workers doing their jobs remotely fell to 10 percent in March — and as tourism and in-person entertainment have largely resumed. The public “may be moving toward the idea that ‘the Covid era’ of the U.S. economy is done,” one economist said.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: April 3, 2022
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, April 3, 2022.
content: A picture caption with an article on Page 4 about the many books returned after New York’s public library systems ended late fees misstates the author and title of a work shown. It is “Ninon de Lenclos” by Emile Magne, not “Magne” by Ninon de Lenclos.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Traub
title: Estelle Harris, George’s Mother on ‘Seinfeld,’ Dies at 93
description: Employing a high-powered screech, she took maternal exasperation and paranoia to comedic heights as one of the show’s most frequently recurring characters.
content: Estelle Harris, who hyperventilated her way into the hearts of millions of “Seinfeld” fans as George’s mother, Estelle Costanza, died on Saturday in Palm Desert, Calif. She was 93.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Safiullah Padshah and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
title: Taliban Outlaw Opium Poppy Cultivation in Afghanistan
description: The move will have far-reaching consequences for the many farmers who turned to the illicit crop as a brutal drought and economic crisis have gripped the country.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — The Taliban announced on Sunday that cultivating opium poppy in Afghanistan was banned, a move that will have far-reaching consequences for the many farmers who have turned to the illicit crop as a brutal drought and economic crisis have gripped the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex W. Palmer, Jack D'Isidoro, Dan Powell, John Woo, Dan Farrell and Devin Murphy
title: The Sunday Read: ‘They Came to Help Migrants. Now, Europe Has Turned on Them.’
description: The legal ordeal of two aid workers shows that anti-migrant attitudes in Greece and across Europe have hardened to the point that such helpers have become political. targets.
content: Exploring the personal experiences of Sara Mardini and Seán Binder, two volunteers who were arrested in February 2018 after helping migrants cross safely into Lesbos, Greece, the journalist Alex W. Palmer outlines the complex situation aid workers in Europe find themselves in: increasingly demonized by local authorities while also facing pressure from different ends of the international political spectrum.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Yaqoob Akbary and Kiana Hayeri
title: ‘Fighting Was Easier’: Taliban Take On a Treacherous, Avalanche-Prone Pass
description: After overthrowing the government, the Taliban are now trying to save what’s left of the roads they spent years blowing up, with none more critical than a two-mile-high pass through the Hindu Kush.
content: THE SALANG PASS, Afghanistan — The Taliban commander’s sneakers had soaked through from the melting snow, but that was the least of his problems. It was avalanche season in the Salang Pass, a rugged cut of switchback roads that gash through the Hindu Kush mountains in northern Afghanistan like some man-made insult to nature, and he was determined to keep the essential trade route open during his first season as its caretaker.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Thunder Lizard
description: Derek J. Angell opens our solving week with a roar.
content: MONDAY PUZZLE — First, let’s congratulate Tyler Hinman, the winner of the grand prize at the American Crossword Puzzle Tournament, who has now won the tournament seven times. In addition, congratulations to Dan Feyer and David Plotkin, Mr. Hinman’s opponents in the A Division. Finally, congratulations to Sid Sivakumar, the winner of the Wordle competition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Cameron
title: Opposition leaders accuse Pakistan’s prime minister of high treason.
description: Shehbaz Sharif, the leader of the opposition, said Prime Minister Imran Khan had violated the Constitution.
content: Opposition leaders in Pakistan reacted with outrage to Prime Minister Imran Khan’s move to dissolve Parliament, accusing him of high treason and subverting the country’s constitutional order.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: The Future of Tennis, Carlos Alcaraz, Has Arrived
description: The 18-year-old Spaniard recently aced two significant American tournaments, reaching the semifinals at Indian Wells and winning the Miami Open.
content: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla. — In a decade or so, after Carlos Alcaraz has piled up the Grand Slam tournament trophies, a four-week stretch in early 2022 may stand out as the time he took over tennis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: Review: Two Sopranos Make an ‘Elektra’ Both Mythic and Human
description: At the Metropolitan Opera, Nina Stemme and Lise Davidsen are a blazing pair as sisters in a revival of Strauss’s work.
content: Behind the glorious excess of Strauss’s “Elektra” — the libretto’s mythic setting, the score’s unsparing terror — is something smaller: a starkly framed family portrait, albeit one knocked off the wall and scratched up by shards of shattered glass.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katerina Sergatskova
title: We Will Fight for Every Brick of Ukraine
description: The fight for every single building has taught many Ukrainians to fight for their home, city and country.
content: Since the beginning of the Russian invasion of Ukraine, thousands of buildings across the country have been destroyed by cruise missiles, aerial bombs and shells. Entire cities — Mariupol, Izium and Volnovakha — are almost demolished. In Kharkiv, some of the most important architectural monuments of the Soviet era and the prerevolutionary period have suffered extensive damage. A number of UNESCO World Heritage sites and architectural treasures are under threat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Davey Alba
title: The Latest Covid Misinformation Star Says He Invented the Vaccines
description: Dr. Robert Malone says he helped invent mRNA vaccines and has been wronged for decades. Now he’s spreading unfounded claims about the vaccines and the virus.
content: MADISON, Va. — “I haven’t been able to ride a horse in months,” Dr. Robert Malone said from his 50-acre horse farm about two hours southwest of Washington. “It’s just a constant barrage of requests for assistance.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andy Furillo, Shawn Hubler and Eduardo Medina
title: At Least 6 Dead and 12 Wounded in Mass Shooting in Sacramento, Police Say
description: Multiple shooters were involved in the incident that occurred outside crowded bars downtown early Sunday, according to authorities.
content: SACRAMENTO — After more than two years of empty streets and withering commerce, California’s capital city seemed to be getting back to its pre-pandemic self this weekend. Thousands turned out for a concert at the downtown Golden 1 Center featuring Tyler, the Creator, and crowds filled the nearby bars, spilling into the spring night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Skandha Gunasekara and Emily Schmall
title: Sri Lanka’s Cabinet Resigns as Street Protests Pressure Government
description: The midnight resignations, amid an escalating economic crisis, leave only the president, Gotabaya Rajapaksa, and his brother, the prime minister, in a cabinet that has been dominated by their family.
content: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka — Sri Lanka’s cabinet resigned en masse on Sunday amid street protests and a dire economic crisis, the outgoing health minister said, leading to a vacuum in the leadership of a country largely controlled by its president’s powerful family.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: Herschel Walker, the Worst Candidate, Trump-Approved
description: Why would Trump urge the former football star to run for the Senate in Georgia? There are a few reasons, all of them part of a callous racial calculus.
content: Let’s just be blunt. No one, and I mean not one person, would seriously believe that Herschel Walker, the former football star and current leading contender for the Republican Senate nomination in Georgia, was at the top of his class at the University of Georgia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Billy Witz
title: Leaky Black Has a Lot on His Mind, And That’s OK
description: Black, a Tar Heels player known more for other elements of his game besides scoring, has become more comfortable talking about his anxiety.
content: NEW ORLEANS — What had gotten into Leaky Black? It was an innocuous question, asked after Black, a once-reluctant shooter whose place in the North Carolina lineup is owed to so many other tasks done well, scored a season-high 13 points and knocked in all three 3-pointers he attempted — including one that put the Tar Heels ahead to stay — in an overtime win at Louisville.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler and Jill Cowan
title: Flurry of New Laws Move Blue and Red States Further Apart
description: A wave of legislation, particularly in the West, is making states “not only a little different but radically different,” says one expert on government.
content: SACRAMENTO — After the governor of Texas ordered state agencies to investigate parents for child abuse if they provide certain medical treatments to their transgender children, California lawmakers proposed a law making the state a refuge for transgender youths and their families.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ezra Klein
title: The Enemies of Liberalism Are Showing Us What It Really Means
description: Ukraine’s refusal to bend the knee to Vladimir Putin has reminded the West that life under liberalism is worth fighting for.
content: “After three decades of dominance, liberalism is losing its hold on Western minds,” Matthew Rose writes in his powerful new book, “A World After Liberalism.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anatoly Kurmanaev and David Bolaños
title: Economist Accused of Harassment Appears Set to Become Costa Rica’s President
description: Preliminary results showed Rodrigo Chaves with a big lead over José María Figueres, who conceded. Mr. Chaves has pledged to overhaul the political system that turned Costa Rica into a model of stability.
content: Rodrigo Chaves, a former World Bank official who has promised to shake up the political system of Central America’s most stable nation, was on track to become Costa Rica’s new president, according to preliminary election results on Sunday night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Natalia Yermak and Tyler Hicks
title: ‘This Is True Barbarity’: Life and Death Under Russian Occupation
description: The town of Trostyanets was occupied by Russian forces for a month before the Ukrainian military liberated it. Residents described weeks of hunger and horror.
content: TROSTYANETS, Ukraine — The last three Russian soldiers in this Ukrainian town are in the morgue, their uniforms bloodied and torn. The first one’s face is frozen in pain. The second has his wooden pipe in his lap. The third is stuffed in his sleeping bag.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SUNDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Bill Fries, Singer Known for 1970s Trucking Ballad ‘Convoy,’ Dies at 93
description: Mr. Fries, who performed under the stage name C.W. McCall, was an ad executive before he scored a hit with “Convoy,” a CB radio-inspired ode to renegade truckers.
content: Bill Fries, the deep-voiced country singer known as C.W. McCall, who turned an ad campaign for an Iowa bread company into the outlaw trucker anthem, “Convoy,” which reached No. 1 on the charts in 1976 and inspired a Sam Peckinpah movie, died on Friday at his home in Ouray, Colo. He was 93.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Bailey
title: Stream These 10 Titles Before They Leave Netflix This Month
description: U.S. subscribers are losing a bunch of titles in April. Here are the best of the bunch.
content: Oscar season is over (finally), but this month’s slate of movies leaving Netflix in the United States is full of winners and nominees past and present, as well as a handful of cult items and action epics. Toss these titles — nine movies and one favorite ’90s TV show — into your list before they’re gone. (Dates reflect the final day a title is available.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Billy Witz
title: Kansas Runs Past Villanova to Get to the N.C.A.A. Final, Avenging a 2018 Loss
description: The Jayhawks took a 10-0 lead in the opening minutes and never trailed. They will play the winner of the Duke-North Carolina game on Monday night for the national championship.
content: NEW ORLEANS — When Kansas Coach Bill Self sat down in recent days to look at film of his last trip to the Final Four, he could not stomach watching more than 12 minutes. It is easy to imagine his gut churning, his palms getting clammy and his head starting to spin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Marchese
title: Thomas Piketty Thinks America Is Primed for Wealth Redistribution
description: The French economist has hope for the country that, to a large extent, invented high, progressive taxation of income.
content: The French economist has hope for the country that, to a large extent, invented high, progressive taxation of income.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 2022 Grammys: See All the Stars on the Red Carpet
description: Before the album of the year, the fashion of the night.
content: Before the album of the year, the fashion of the night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Axel Boada and Nailah Morgan
title: Video Appears to Show Civilians Killed in Bucha
description: Ukrainian officials accused Russian forces of killing civilians in Bucha, Ukraine, a suburb northwest of Kyiv. Russian officials denied the allegations.
content: Ukrainian officials accused Russian forces of killing civilians in Bucha, Ukraine, a suburb northwest of Kyiv. Russian officials denied the allegations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Week
description: Bryan Washington wrote about the consoling powers of kakuni, seared pork belly simmered in sake, soy sauce and sugar.
content: Good morning. “Every dish exists in its own continuum,” Bryan Washington wrote in The New York Times Magazine this week, “but they become interconnected through our personal experience. You eat a meal that blows your mind. That dish works its way into your life. One year, you go heavier on the garlic. The next, a little lighter on the char. Or maybe you grow to prefer more chile, more lime, more heat, until a meal’s history becomes interlocked with your own.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Value of Camps for Grieving Children
description: “Children’s grief is complex and nuanced and deeply experienced — but, sadly, very misunderstood.” Also: College rankings; war refugees; Ukraine and Finland.
content: To the Editor:
